advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 1000 ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT(1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The calculator was sold with a very helpful manual (Calculator Decision-Making Sourcebook) giving step- by-step examples for the best techniques used for solving mathematical, statistical and scientific problems, as well as programming tips.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. PAGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is for the Micromachine 4000, but a picture of the Micromachine 2000 and 3000 is inserted.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #5 (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">If you could talk to Thomas Edison, he'd tell you what it was like to turn the light on in 1879. You could tell him about some bright idea of the 20th century... particularly, a technological phenomenon that can handle everything from solar heat control to lighting you home via voice command. The Apple personal computer...<br> ... With Apple, Edison could've written a program to determine why some filaments burned longer than others...</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMO PIC #6</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to its optional modem, the TO-7/70 could be connected to the Teletel communication network. This skilled photograph is browsing the Liberation (popular french newspaper) site. <br><br> But there are still no cables shown here ! How the whole system is running ?!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> IEEE INTERFACE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> The Acorn IEEE interface enables full implementation of the IEEE standard 488-1978. IEEE488 is also known, and is equivalent to IEC625-1 (in Europe), and GPIB or HP-IB (Hewlett Packard General Purpose Interface Bus)...<br> ...The interface can support a network of up to 14 other IEEE-488 compatible devices. Devices can be interconnected in a star or linear fashion. </font><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8bs.com</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The facts speak for themselves. The QUAY 500 SERIES offers more for the money than North Star Horizon computers...<br><br> ...The bottom line is simple. There is a new star in the computer field. The 500 SERIES by Quay. It outshines all of the competition.<br><br></font> A little pretentious tone!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It has not finished to surprise you"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>UK advert from Personal Computer World magazine, October 1983</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD #3 (1983) </strong></font><br><blockquote>As harware arguments wasn't sufficient, NothStar tried to promote software compatability and services.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SAME IN GERMAN</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert from the Nieman-Marcus catalog.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DICK SMITH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Price list close-up in Australian$:<br> Basic CAT computer X-7500 <b>$1195.00</b><br> Disk Drive X-7505 <b>$1495.00</b><br> Disk Controller X-7510 <b>$149.95</b><br> Emulator Cartridge X-7530 <b>$149.95</b><br> Dual Joysticks X-7520 <b>$49.95</b><br> RF Modulator X-7550 <b>$49.95</b><br> RS-232C Serial Adaptor X-7515 <b>$149.95</b><br> Printer Cable (Centronics) X-7540 <b>$844.95</b><br> Filer Utilities Disk with DOS & Manual X-7512 <b>$59.95</b><br> High resolution RVB monitor X-1193 <b>$995.00</b><br> RGB Cable X-7560 <b>$44.95</b><br> High Res. Green Monitor X-1220 <b>$395.00</b></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST +4 SALES, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://osaki.cool.ne.jp/hc/computer/canon/canon.html#x07">Handheld computer & Pocket calculator Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Maxi Basic Yeno SC 3000 : program at full gallop"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of Junya Kubota </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (FEB. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT (MAY 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>No info in this advert about the display that could be used (TV, composite, colour, B/W?)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT(1982) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: Microsoft Extended Basic (MSX Basic V1.0) + Japanese Worprocessor
computer.coprocessor: Video chip compatible with the Texas Instruments TMS 9918/A or TMS 9928/A (Japan : 60 Hz) or TMS 9929/A (Europe : 50 Hz)
computer.description:
MSX 1 computer with 64 KB RAM, two cartridge slots and wordprocessor software built-in.
The FS-4000 was sold as a wordprocessor system based on the MSX technology. It has a 24 dots thermal printer built-in the case. It was available in black or white case. It is equiped with MSX JE-1, Kanji 1, and chinese characters ROM...

emulator.description: A Bresilian MSX Emulator written in 100% assembler
emulator.name: BrMSX

emulator.description: A MSX Emulator for Win95 and Win NT + Direct X
emulator.name: RuMSX

emulator.description: fMSX is a portable MSX emulator ported on : Amiga OS, Mac OS, MS DOS, OS/2, Sony Playstation, Risc OS, Towns OS, Unix / X, Win95 / NT, X68K.
emulator.name: fMSX official Homepage

emulator.description: This new MSX emulator can reproduce, among many other MSX, MSX2and MSX2+ machines, both Panasonic Turbo-R models. Be sure to get the catapult frontend and the system roms from FUNET.
emulator.name: openMSX - The MSX emulator that aims for perfection.

computer.graphics: Mode 2 : 256 x 192 with 16 colors (Hires mode)Mode 3 : 64 x 48 with 16 colors (Multi colour mode)32 sprites

MEGA RAM DISK 256|||from DDX (Brazil)|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEGA RAM DISK 256</strong></font><br><strong>> from DDX (Brazil)</strong><br><blockquote>This is the famous Megaram cartridge made in Brzail, used to play all Konami cracked Megarom games.6401999243</blockquote>

Panasonic FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W|||Scanner/Printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PANASONIC FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W</strong></font><br><strong>> Scanner/Printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>The FS-IFA1 is the printer/scanner interface (left on the picture) and the FW-RSU1W is the handheld scanner (right on the picture). These expansions are for MSX2 systems.</blockquote>
Sony HBI-232|||RS232c cartridge|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SONY HBI-232</strong></font><br><strong>> RS232c cartridge</strong><br><blockquote>Used to connect serial printers.</blockquote>

Yamaha mouse #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This mouse was compatible with all MSX systems. It connects to the first Joystick port.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>
Yamaha mouse #2||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Brand new!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>

Philips VW0020|||80-col dot-matrix printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS VW0020</strong></font><br><strong>> 80-col dot-matrix printer</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a rebadged version of the Seikosha GP-500.<br> It was a 80-column, 50 CPS model with a 7x5 dot matrix head.<br> Commodore and Atari used same hardware basis for their MPS-801 and 1029 printers. </blockquote>

Sanyo DR-202||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANYO DR-202</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ADSS system allowed to quickly search a specific program in a cassette tape and load it. Seach time for a C60 cassette was less than 1 minute.</blockquote>

Bit-corder||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> BIT-CORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cassete recorder dedicated to Hit-Bit MSX systems, though it could be used with any home computers.</blockquote>
